definition:
In the theory of stochastic processes, the term *finite-variation
process* is used to refer to a process $X_t$ whose paths are
right-continuous and have finite total variation over every compact time
interval, with probability one. See, for example, the Poisson process.

It can be shown that any function on the real numbers with finite total
variation has left and right limits everywhere. Consequently, finite
variation processes are always cadlag.
